sen.j: 橘 南谿（たちばな なんけい、宝暦3年4月21日 (旧暦)（1753年5月23日） - 文化 (元号)2年4月10日 (旧暦)（1805年5月8日））は、江戸時代後期の医者。
sen.e: Nankei TACHIBANA (May, 23, 1753 - May 8, 1805) was a doctor in the late Edo period.
Nankei TACHIBANA (May, 23, 1753 - May 8, 1805) was a doctor in the late Edo period.
Nankei TACHIBANA (May, 23, 1753 - May 8, 1805) was a doctor in the late Edo period.

sen.j: 文をよくし、紀行『東遊記』、『西遊記』が知られる。
sen.e: He wrote books such as pieces of travel writing, "Toyuki (Journey to the East)" and "Saiyuki (Journey to the West)" which were well-known.
He was into literature and wrote books such as pieces of travel writing, "Toyuki (Journey to the East)" and "Saiyuki (Journey to the West)."
sen.cmt: 文をよくしの部分をwhich were well-knownから was into literatureに訂正しました。
sen.e: He was into literature and wrote books such as pieces of travel writing, "Toyuki (Journey to the East)" and "Saiyuki (Journey to the West)."

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 伊勢国久居（現在の三重県久居市）西鷹跡町に生まれた。
sen.e: He was born in Nishitakatomachi in Hisai, Ise Province (present Hisai City in Mie Prefecture).
He was born in Nishitakatomachi, Hisai, Ise Province (present Hisai City in Mie Prefecture).
He was born in Nishitakatomachi, Hisai, Ise Province (present Hisai City in Mie Prefecture).

sen.j: 久居藤堂藩に勤める、250石の宮川氏の五男であった。
sen.e: He was the fifth son of the Miyagawa clan who worked for Hisai Todo Domain and was given 250 koku (a unit of volume) of rice.
He was the fifth son of the Miyagawa clan who worked for Hisai Todo Domain and was given 250 koku (a unit of volume) of rice.
He was the fifth son of the Miyagawa clan who worked for Hisai Todo Domain and was given 250 koku (a unit of volume) of rice.

sen.j: 宮川春暉（はるあきら）、字は恵風、通称東市。
sen.e: His real name was Haruakira Miyagawa with his azana (adult male's nickname) of Keifu (恵風) and he was commonly called Toichi (東市).
His real name was Haruakira Miyagawa with his azana (adult male's nickname) of Keifu (恵風) and he was commonly called Toichi (東市).
His real name was Haruakira Miyagawa with his azana (adult male's nickname) of Keifu (恵風) and he was commonly called Toichi (東市).

sen.j: 後に称した『橘』は妻の姓である。
sen.e: "Tachibana" which he took later was the surname of his wife.
"Tachibana" which he took later was the surname of his wife.
"Tachibana" which he took later was the surname of his wife.

sen.j: 南谿・梅華仙史を号した。
sen.e: He took the names of Nankei and Baika.
He took the names of Nankei and Senshi BAIKA.
sen.cmt: 仙史の訳が抜けていました。
sen.e: He took the names of Nankei and Senshi BAIKA.

sen.j: 幼いときから漢学を習った。
sen.e: Since his childhood, he learned the study of the Chinese classics.
Since his childhood, he learned the study of the Chinese classics.
Since his childhood, he learned the study of the Chinese classics.

sen.j: 14歳のとき、父が没した。
sen.e: His father died when he was 14.
His father died when he was 14.
His father died when he was 14.

sen.j: 明和8年（1771年）19歳のとき、医学を志して京都に上り、母と住んだ。
sen.e: When he was 19 in 1771, he went to Kyoto to study medicine and lived with his mother.
When he was 19 in 1771, he went to Kyoto to study medicine and lived with his mother.
When he was 19 in 1771, he went to Kyoto to study medicine and lived with his mother.

sen.j: 大阪、伏見に転居し、28歳のころ、京都に戻った。
sen.e: He moved to Osaka and Fushimi, and then went back to Kyoto when he was 28.
He moved to Osaka and Fushimi, and then went back to Kyoto when he was 28.
He moved to Osaka and Fushimi, and then went back to Kyoto when he was 28.

sen.j: 天明元年（1781年）夏、29歳のとき、医書『痘瘡水鏡録』を出版した。
sen.e: When he was 29 in the summer of 1781, he published "Tososuikyoroku (Medical guidebook for smallpox)".
In the summer of 1781, he published "Tososuikyoroku (Medical guidebook for smallpox)" when he was 29.
sen.cmt: 文の順番を変えました。
sen.e: In the summer of 1781, he published "Tososuikyoroku (Medical guidebook for smallpox)" when he was 29.

sen.j: 母を喪った。
sen.e: He lost his mother.
He lost his mother.
He lost his mother.

sen.j: その後数年、旅を多くした。
sen.e: He often traveled for several years after the loss of his mother.
He often traveled for several years after the loss of his mother.
He often traveled for several years after the loss of his mother.

sen.j: すなわち、天明2年春 - 翌年夏：西国・鹿児島／天明4年秋：信濃／天明5年秋 - 翌年夏：北陸・奥羽・富山。
sen.e: He traveled around the western part of Japan and Kagoshima from the spring of 1782 to summer of the following year, Shinano Province in the fall of 1784, and the Hokuriku and Ou regions and Toyama from the fall of 1785 to summer of the following year.

He traveled around the western part of Japan and Kagoshima from the spring of 1782 to summer of the following year, Shinano Province in the fall of 1784, and the Hokuriku and Ou regions and Toyama from the fall of 1785 to summer of the following year.

He traveled around the western part of Japan and Kagoshima from the spring of 1782 to summer of the following year, Shinano Province in the fall of 1784, and the Hokuriku and Ou regions and Toyama from the fall of 1785 to summer of the following year.

sen.j: 旅の目的は、「臨床医としての見聞を広めるため」と記し、各地で治療もした。
sen.e: He noted that "the purpose of the travel is to broaden my knowledge as a clinical doctor" and provided treatments in various places as well.
He noted that "the purpose of the travel is to broaden my knowledge as a clinical doctor" and provided treatments in various places as well.
He noted that "the purpose of the travel is to broaden my knowledge as a clinical doctor" and provided treatments in various places as well.

sen.j: 天明3年（1783年）6月、31歳のとき、小石元俊に指導されて、伏見で刑死人の解剖を執刀し、その所見が、絵師吉村蘭洲によるとして残る。
sen.e: When he was 31 in June, 1783, he dissected an executed dead body under the instruction of Genshun KOISHI in Fushimi, and the observation was recorded by a painter, Ranshu YOSHIMIURA.
sen.cmt: 小石元俊は<http://www.nnn.co.jp/dainichi/rensai/naniwa/naniwa070929.html>を参照吉村蘭洲は<http://kotobank.jp/word/%E5%90%89%E6%9D%91%E8%98%AD%E6%B4%B2>を参照
sen.e: When he was 31 in June, 1783, he dissected an executed dead body under the instruction of Genshun KOISHI in Fushimi, and the observation was recorded by a painter, Ranshu YOSHIMIURA.
When he was 31 in June, 1783, he dissected an executed dead body under the instruction of Genshun KOISHI in Fushimi, and the observation was recorded by a painter, Ranshu YOSHIMIURA.

sen.j: 天明6年（1786年）12月、内膳司（天皇の食事を調達する役所）の史生に、翌年2月、位階に、同3月、石見介に任じられた。
sen.e: After he became a shisho (person who performed miscellaneous duties about documents) of Naizenshi (Imperial Table Office) in December, 1786, he received a court rank in February of the following year, and then was appointed to Iwami no suke (Assistant Governor of Iwami Province) in March of the same year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After he became a shisho (person who performed miscellaneous duties about documents) of Naizenshi (Imperial Table Office) in December, 1786, he received a court rank in February of the following year, and then was appointed to Iwami no suke (Assistant Governor of Iwami Province) in March of the same year.

After he became a shisho (person who performed miscellaneous duties about documents) of Naizenshi (Imperial Table Office) in December, 1786, he received a court rank in February of the following year, and then was appointed to Iwami no suke (Assistant Governor of Iwami Province) in March of the same year.

sen.j: 11月、光格天皇の大嘗祭に連なった。
sen.e: In December, he attended Daijosai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) for Emperor Kokaku.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In December, he attended Daijosai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) for Emperor Kokaku.
In December, he attended Daijosai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) for Emperor Kokaku.

sen.j: 天明8年1月、類焼の難に遭って伏見に仮寓し、寛政2年秋、京都に新居を設けた。
sen.e: He resided temporarily in Fushimi due to a spreading fire in January, 1788 and then built new home in Kyoto in the fall of 1790.
He resided temporarily in Fushimi due to a spreading fire in January, 1788 and then built new home in Kyoto in the fall of 1790.
He resided temporarily in Fushimi due to a spreading fire in January, 1788 and then built new home in Kyoto in the fall of 1790.

sen.j: この頃、消化器と喘息を病んだ。
sen.e: Around that time, he suffered from digestive disease and asthma.
Around that time, he suffered from digestive disease and asthma.
Around that time, he suffered from digestive disease and asthma.

sen.j: 寛政6年9月（1794年）、従六位下になった。
sen.e: In September, 1794, he received Jurokuinoge (Junior Sixth Rank, Lower Grade).
In September, 1794, he received Jurokuinoge (Junior Sixth Rank, Lower Grade).
In September, 1794, he received Jurokuinoge (Junior Sixth Rank, Lower Grade).

sen.j: 寛政7年（1795年）3月『西遊記』（せいゆうき）を、同8月『東遊記』を版行した。
sen.e: He published "Saiyuki (Journey to the West)" in March, 1795, and "Toyuki (Journey to the East)" in August of the same year.
He published "Saiyuki (Journey to the West)" in March, 1795, and "Toyuki (Journey to the East)" in August of the same year.
He published "Saiyuki (Journey to the West)" in March, 1795, and "Toyuki (Journey to the East)" in August of the same year.

sen.j: 嘗ての旅の記録の筆写本が回覧されていて、それの上梓を書肆が望んだのである。
sen.e: The manuscripts of his past travel reports had been circulated and a publisher wanted to publish the books.
The manuscripts of his past travel reports had been circulated and a publisher wanted to publish the books.
The manuscripts of his past travel reports had been circulated and a publisher wanted to publish the books.

sen.j: 『西遊記』には伴蒿蹊が、『東遊記』には松本愚山が序を寄せた。
sen.e: Kokei BAN and Guzan MATSUMOTO wrote a preface to "Saiyuki" and "Toyuki", respectively.
Kokei BAN and Guzan MATSUMOTO wrote a preface to "Saiyuki" and "Toyuki", respectively.
Kokei BAN and Guzan MATSUMOTO wrote a preface to "Saiyuki" and "Toyuki", respectively.

sen.j: 寛政8年（1796年）4月、44歳のとき、石見介の職を辞した。
sen.e: When he was 44 in April, 1796, he resigned Iwami no suke.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: When he was 44 in April, 1796, he resigned Iwami no suke.
When he was 44 in April, 1796, he resigned Iwami no suke.

sen.j: 翌月剃髪し『梅仙』の法名を称した。
sen.e: The following month, he took the tonsure and took the homyo (priest's name) of "Baisen".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処「梅仙」の読み不明
sen.e: The following month, he shaved his head to become a Buddhist priest and took the homyo (priest's name) of "Baisen".
sen.cmt: took the tonsureを shaved his head to become a Buddhist priestに訂正しました。
sen.e: The following month, he shaved his head to become a Buddhist priest and took the homyo (priest's name) of "Baisen".

sen.j: 寛政9年1月、『東遊記後篇』を刊行した。
sen.e: He published "Toyuki kohen (the sequel to Journey to the East)" in January, 1796.
He published "Toyuki kohen (the sequel to Journey to the East)" in January, 1796.
He published "Toyuki kohen (the sequel to Journey to the East)" in January, 1796.

sen.j: 冬の南紀を巡った。
sen.e: He traveled around the Nanki area in winter.
He traveled around the Nanki area in winter.
He traveled around the Nanki area in winter.

sen.j: 翌年6月、『西遊記続篇』を刊行した。
sen.e: In June of the following year, he published "Saiyuki zokuhen (the sequel to Journey to the West)".
In June of the following year, he published "Saiyuki zokuhen (the sequel to Journey to the West)."
sen.cmt: コンマを"の内側に入れました。
sen.e: In June of the following year, he published "Saiyuki zokuhen (the sequel to Journey to the West)."

sen.j: 文化2年（1805年）4月10日、転居先の京都東山安井（現在の京都市東山区）で没した。
sen.e: On April 10, 1805, he died in his new home in Higashiyama Yasui, Kyoto (present Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City).
On April 10, 1805, he died in his new home in Higashiyama Yasui, Kyoto (present Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City).
On April 10, 1805, he died in his new home in Higashiyama Yasui, Kyoto (present Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City).
He was 53.
He was 53.
He was 53.

sen.j: 『南谿院殿陽岳義明』。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is Nankeiindenyogakugimei (南谿院殿陽岳義明).
sen.cmt: 「南谿院殿陽岳義明」の読み不明
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is Nankeiindenyogakugimei (南谿院殿陽岳義明).
His posthumous Buddhist name is Nankeiindenyogakugimei (南谿院殿陽岳義明).

sen.j: 墓碑は、京都市左京区黒谷町、金戒光明寺の墓域に残る。
sen.e: His gravestone remains in the cemetery of the Konkai Komyo-ji Temple in Kurodani-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
His gravestone remains in the cemetery of the Konkai Komyo-ji Temple in Kurodani-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
His gravestone remains in the cemetery of the Konkai Komyo-ji Temple in Kurodani-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.e: 1783: "Sasshukoshiden (Stories of dutiful children in Satsuma Province)"

sen.e: 1791: "Shokanron jigen (easy-to-follow treatise on cold damage)" and "Shokanron bunchu (commentary of treatise on cold damage)"

sen.j: 寛政7年（1795）：『西遊記』、『東遊記』、『国語律呂解』（和音階の解説（南谿は琴にたくみであった））
sen.e: 1795: "Saiyuki (Journey to the West)", "Toyuki (Journey to the East)" and "Kokugoritsuryokai (explanation of Japanese musical scale)" (Nankei was good at playing koto [Japanese harp]).

sen.e: 1796: "Shokan gaiden (side story of cold damage)
